title: "raw" JSON+LD metadata extractor
body:
Our existing metadata extractors transform metadata from one form into another, primarily turning them into JSON-serializable structures, and JSON+LD (if we are lucky). The question whether it is possible to implement extractors in another language came up in the past, but is not currently possible.

I had the realization that we are missing the most simple "extractor" that would make it straightforward to invent any metadata extraction/harmonization/conversion in any language while still being compatible with the rest of the metadata handling (aggregation, transport, ...).

I propose to implement a `json-ld` extractor. All it would do is to check if a metadata file in JSON(+LD) format exists, and return its content. The location would be configurable. Initially, only dataset-level metadata would be supported. Later on per-file metadata support could be added. Possible mechanisms
for this could be:

- side-car files
- special annex metadata key
- something totally different.

With such an extractor, anyone can implement any algorithm to produce optimal metadata. An algorithm could be registered in a dataset as a `procedure` that can run automatically -- thereby not breaking the paradigm that "metadata should be update-able in an automated fashion to make it future-ready".

Given that datalad has no idea what such metadata from be made of or come from, we should also allow for assigning an arbitrary name for it. Maybe default to `custom`, but allow for something else. This may require a change in the common code part of the extraction handling.
